awd_titl_txt: Do spatial traits (geography) or species traits better explain vulnerability and resilience of plants to external threats?
awd_abstract_narration:
This project identifies the elements of plant biodiversity that are most vulnerable and, conversely, most resilient to the interacting threats of habitat loss, via land-use change and urbanization, as well as environmental variability and related changes in wildfire regimes. Identifying generalities in the factors that confer vulnerability or resilience to species based on their innate characteristics (their species traits) and where they naturally occur (their geography or spatial traits) in relation to threats, is the intellectual contribution of this project and to geography and the spatial sciences. Results from this study permit a prioritization of species and ecosystems and identify locations for management and conservation of plant diversity. This project will be conducted at the University of California Riverside (UCR), a Hispanic-serving institution located in one of the most socio-economically and culturally diverse regions in the United States. The PIs will leverage existing STEM education initiatives at UCR to engage undergraduates in local K-12 classrooms through the CalTeach program, where they will introduce spatial science and models as a framework for understanding geographic concepts, ecological principles and pressing conservation issues.

The vulnerability of a plant species to threat depends on their distribution (biogeography) in relation to these threats, as well as their species traits. Plants may be long or short lived (redwood trees versus poppies), escape habitat fragmentation and loss because their ecological niche places them in locations undesirable for development, or they may have traits that allow them to recover their populations following fire (fire-stimulated seed germination, or resprouting from underground parts). In a changing environment, plants can only move (migrate) away from threats intergenerationally, mainly via seed dispersal. This project identifies the general aspects of spatial traits (biogeography) versus species traits that confer more or less vulnerability to plants under global change in the coming century as human populations grow and land-use changes. The PIs use simulation modeling to project the population growth or decline for a wide range of plant species that differ in their disturbance-response and other species traits (life form: trees, shrubs, herbs; fire-response; and morphological traits) and their biogeography (coastal, mountain and desert distributions) to identify generalities regarding their vulnerability to threats. They develop and use statistical models of spatially explicit fire risk and species biogeography using modern regression and machine learning methods and use those models to project spatially explicit changes under different land-use and environmental scenarios. The PIs construct plant population models using data from the COMPADRE Plant Matrix Database and will extract species traits from the TRY Plant Trait Database. This project focuses on the biodiversity of the California Floristic Province, but trends identified will be broadly relevant throughout the entire western U.S. where water-limited ecosystems are strongly impacted by increasing environmental variability and increasing wildfire.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to understand which plant traits and spatial factors contribute to extinction risk in the California Floristic Province (CFP), a biodiversity hotspot with a Mediterranean climate. By combining ecological theories, plant demographic data, and projections of land use, climate change, and fire patterns, we developed models to predict how these factors interact and influence extinction risk.

Intellectual Merits

Fire Patterns and Climate Change

We created fire distribution models to predict future fire patterns under climate change in different regions of California. By comparing state-wide models to region-specific ones, we found that the geographical extent of models significantly affects fire predictions, emphasizing the need for regionally tailored fire management strategies.

Species Distribution Modeling

To address uncertainties in predicting species distributions, we tested different consensus methods and introduced a new approach called SHAPE. This method improved predictions by better handling complex environmental data. We modeled the current and future distributions of 82 plant species in the CFP, highlighting that variability in predictions was more influenced by the modeling methods than by climate change scenarios.

Population Modeling and Vulnerability

We examined whether geography or life history traits determine plant species' vulnerability to climate change. Using six representative species from the CFP, we integrated their demographic data with distribution models to assess population decline risks. We found that while habitat changes mainly drive overall population declines, species' specific life history traits significantly impact local population dynamics, especially in fire-prone areas.

Fire Management

For Tecate cypress, a fire-dependent plant, we developed a detailed population model to determine the best fire management practices. Results suggest that fire suppression should be frequent and widespread when resources are ample, but more targeted when resources are limited.

Threats to Endangered Plants

We compiled a database of threats to California's endangered and threatened plants, revealing that most are endemic to the state. Major threats include invasive species, recreational activities, development, and agriculture. Perennial herbs are particularly vulnerable, with many facing multiple threats.

Key Takeaways

  •  Fire predictions vary significantly with geographic scope, requiring region-specific management.
  • Uncertainty in species distribution models can be reduced with improved methods like SHAPE.
  • Habitat changes are the main driver of population declines, but local dynamics of native plants are influenced by species traits.
  • Effective fire management for obligate seeding species depends on balancing the extent and frequency of interventions.
  • Endangered plant species in California face multiple, region-specific threats, emphasizing the need for targeted conservation efforts.

Broader Impacts

The project’s broader impacts include the Resilient Restoration project, which trained Native Americans across approximately 30 Tribes in southern California in various stewardship pathways. Participants received training in native plant conservation, propagation, restoration, indigenous fire stewardship, and climate adaptation tools. The project's outputs, including maps and population models, were used to help visualize and plan stewardship and management of culturally significant plants on Tribal lands. These results were also shared with California natural resource agencies and the USFWS to integrate Indigenous Knowledge in conservation planning.

Collaborating with San Diego State University, the Climate Science Alliance, and the Tribal Working Group (TWG), the project contributed to the design of an ArcGIS Online interactive platform for data sharing. This portal includes species distribution models, population models, and fire distribution models under climate change scenarios for culturally significant plants. Undergraduate students at UCR, under mentorship, prepared background information on these species, contributing to an interactive restoration guide for Tribal land planning.

An upper division online course, "Global Change Biology," was developed at UCR, utilizing examples from this project. The course, highlighting multiple threats like climate change, fire, and urban growth, is available across the University of California system and integrates Indigenous perspectives through guest speakers and hands-on activities. 

This project has been instrumental in providing research and teaching opportunities in conservation ecology to under-represented undergraduate students at UC Riverside (UCR), where many students are the first in their families to attend college. Five female undergraduates were mentored by the PIs, guiding them through various aspects of conservation research. One student completed her Honors capstone project on threats to endangered plant species in California, and another participated in an Undergraduate Summer Research Program to encourage Latinx students to pursue research in the environmental sciences, eventually interning in Washington DC. These students were trained in data collection, quality control, graph and figure creation, scientific writing, paper critique, and conservation biology principles.

In addition to undergraduate training, three graduate students and two postdocs received training and mentorship. One of these students now holds a postdoctoral position, another received her MS degree and will pursue a PhD, and a third student has reached PhD candidacy. Two Postdocs have advanced their careers by attaining specialist research positions.
